rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Somatosensory evoked potentials in man
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Science ls based upon belief in the concept of causality; in Newtonian terms of direct 'cause' and effect or, in the more recent terms of relativity theory and population statistics, of 'causes' and 'probabilistic effects'. This is mentioned because any attempt to understand brain function immediately involves description and quantification of apparent situation, or stimulus induced effects or 'responses'. Until approximately 80 years ago, the only responses available for study were either of a subjective or of an overt 'behavioural' (motor) nature. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Factors affecting the conductivity of cortical pathways
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The production of long-lasting changes in the conductivity of trans-synaptic cortical pathways by homosynaptic and heterosynaptic conditioning procedures has been investigated. Spike responses of single neurones to repetitive submaximal stimulation were recorded with extracellular microelectrodes in the isolated slab preparation of the cat cerveau isolé. Conductivity was defined as the proportion of test stimuli evoking an action potential from the recorded cell. During homosynaptic conditioning the rate of stimulation of the test pathway was changed; during heterosynaptic conditioning the cell was activated by a second, differently placed electrode. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effects of growth and athletic training on cardio-respiratory function in exercise
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The effects of athletic training during growth have been studied on the same children, over three years, while engaged in swim training. Resting lung volumes and expiratory flow rates as well as cardio-respiratory functions in exercise were measured and comparison made with 83 normal children. In addition, 14 young adults were studied before and after seasonal athletic training. Swim training during growth was found to significantly increase vital capacity and expiratory flow rates. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Metabolism of 16-alpha-hydroxysteroids in man
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It was in 1930 that the first l6-alpha-hydroxysteroid, namely estriol, was isolated from human pregnancy urine by Marrian (1) and Doisy et al (2). In the ensuing years, a number of 16-alpha-hydroxysteroids, both neutral and phenolic, have been isolated from various sources. A large quantity of l6-alpha-hydroxylated metabolites have been isolated from normal human urine, from the urine of individuals with various diseases and from human pregnancy urine. Neher et al (3) isolated 3-alpha,16-alpha-dihydroxy-5-alpha-pregnan-20-one and 3-alpha,16-alpha-dihydroxy-5-beta-pregnan-20-one from the urine of a subject with the salt-losing form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Glucuronidation of phenols and related compounds
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Glucuronidation in vitro of two classes of compounds, namely the 3-0-methylated metabolites of the catecholamines and two alkaloids (harmalol and harmol) has bean studied. The system employs uridine diphosphate glucuronic acid as the glucuronyl donor, with guinea pig liver microsomes providing the UDP-glucuronyltransferase. Of the substrates tested, normetanephrine, metanephrine, 3-0-methyldopamine, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenethanol, harmalol and harmol are glucuronidated. The conjugative reaction with the last two compounds forms the basis of a simple spectrophotofluorometric method for the measurement of transglucuronidating activity as weIl as of endogenous UDPGA in various tissues. Incorporation of the oxidative step, catalyzed by UDPG dehydrogenase in the presence of NAD allows the measurement of UDPG also. In addition, some hormonal effects on the hepatic concentration of UDPGA in the rat have been investigated: starvation and alloxan decrease the hepatic UDPGA while glucose, hydrocortisone and epinephrine have the opposite effect. Results with insulin injection are, however, inconsistent.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Pharmacological investigations of biologically active urine extracts
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The presence of a substance(s) in extracts of eosinophi1 leucocyte suspensions with antihistamine-like action was first reported in 1950 (Kovacs, 1950). In the past 16 years these findings have been confirmed and considerab1y extended (Vercauteren, 1953; Archer, 1963; Francis et al. 1963 and Kovacs et al. 1963). Recently it was observed that extracts of horse eosinophi1s can antagonize serotonin and bradykinininduced wheal formation as well as histamine-induced bronchoconstriction (Archer, 1963). It has also been reported (Kovacs and Melville, 1962, 1963) that extracts of human and animal urine exert similar activities and can antagonize the effects of histamine, serotonin and bradykinin not only in vitro but also in vivo. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Transport and phosphorylation of choline in mammalian tissues
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: More than hundred years have elapsed and many investigations have been made since choline was first obtained from pig's bile (Strecker 1849) and was named and appeared in chemical literature (Strecker 1862). But its mechanism of action as a dietary factor and its physiological significance 1s still attracting attention from pharmacologists, physiologists and biochemists. Choline has several known metabolic fates. As free choline in nerve tissue, it is a precursor of acetylcholine (Korkes et al 1952). As phosphorylcholine, it acts as a precursor for phospholipid synthesis (Kennedy 1956). As betaine, it is a methyl group donor (Dubnoff 1949). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies of the parietal cell mass
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One of the characteristics of the individual with peptic ulceration is that he is likely to have a large number of parietal cells in his stomach than a normal person. As the parietal cell is responsible for the secretion of gastric acid, it is suggested that the number of parietal cells that an individual has may be related to the presence or absence of peptic ulceration. Two main hypothesis have been advanced to explain variations in the parietal cell mass. Cox has suggested that an increase in the number of parietal cells follows excessive and prolonged application of stimuli for gastric acid secretion. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Short-term production scheduling and equipment dispatching for underground metal mines
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An integrated approach for short-tenn production planning and equipment dispatching for underground metal mines is proposed in this thesis. The salient factors influencing a shift production schedule are controlled by both management and the mine environment. The mine system constraints reflect the inter-play of geological, geomechanical and economic factors. The management goals are considered with respect to the operating policies of draw-point and ore-bin control, and ground control, equipment allocation and ventilation systems. The integration of these various issues constitutes the mining system, which requires flexibility to achieve the production goals under changing mining environments. [...]

Cette thèse propose une méthode d’intégrer la planification à court terme avec 1’ affectation des équipements miniers souterrains. Les principaux facteurs qui influencent l’échéancier de production du quart de travail sont contrôlés à la fois par la gestion et l’environnement minier. Les contraintes du système minier reflètent 11 interaction des facteurs géologiques’ géomécaniques et d 1 évaluation du gisement. Les objectifs de la gestion sont considérés par rapport aux politiques d 1 opération des points de soutirage et le contrôle des réserves de minerai foudroyé, de la distribution des équipements et du système de ventilation. L’intégration de ces facteurs affecte la flexibilité du système minier qui est requise pour atteindre les objectifs de production, pour des conditions de minage changeantes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering, Mining

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The thermal decomposition of vinyl ethyl ether
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is now generally conceded that the decomposition of an organic compound can be realized in two different ways: First, the products may be formed by a single process of rearrangement of atoms. [...] Secondly, the products may be only formed through a series of steps in which the free radicals play the role of an intermediate, i.e., a chain mechanism. Both kinds of mechanism are, of course, possible. In fact, they may be operative simultaneously. The task facing a physical chemist in studying the decomposition of an organic compound, therefore, not only consists of the determination of the chemical change taking place and the rate expression of the over-all process, but also whether the process comes through a rearrangement mechanism or a chain mechanism or both. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The ethanolysis of spruce wood and the structure of lignin
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Recent reviews on the structure of lignin by von Wacek (1) Freudenberg (2), Erdtman (3) and Hibbert (4) have emphasized the essentially aromatic character of lignin and its relationship to coniferyl types. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Freedom in Kantian ethics
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Born in Königsberg, East Prussia, in 1724, Immanuel Kant spent his whole life there, with the exception of a few years when he lived, as a private tutor, with an aristocratic country family not far from the city. His life was centred in the small but growingly important University of Königsberg, which he attended first as a student, and where he later became a "private docent", and eventually a full professor of logic and metaphysics. In the University and its environs Kant lived a life of diligent and brilliant scholarship, refusing proffered appointments and honours, and invitations to larger universities, in order to devote his whole energy to the lifework he set himself. He died at Königsberg in 1804, an old and greatly honored man. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kant, Immanuel, 1724-1804 -- Contributions in concept of free will and determinism
Ethics, Modern -- 18th century
Kant, Immanuel, 1724-1804 -- Contributions in ethics
Free will and determinism

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Athabaskan series at Beaverlodge lake Saskatchewan
rdf:Description.ual:dissertant: Blake, Donald A. W. (Donald Alan Wright), 1925-
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A series of clastic sediments nearly two miles in thickness is exposed in the Beaverlodge Lake area in northern Saskatchewan. It overlies unconformably a complex of highly metamorphosed and deformed ancient rocks. The series consists of first, a basal conglomerate composed of angular fragments, second, a succession of "red" siltstone, sandstone, and arkose, all of which contain pebbles and conglomerate bands and, third, coarse loosely consolidated conglomerates composed of well-rounded fragments. Because of its similarity to the Athabaska Sandstone of Keweenawan Age, south of Lake Athabaska, the series is called the Athabaska Series. Interbedded with sandstone in a zone about halfway up the series are several bodies of highly amygdaloidal basic lava flows. Cutting the structure are narrow basic dykes. The Athabaska Series is believed to have been deposited rapidly under shallow water conditions in a semi-arid temperate climate. Though the series has been deformed and severely faulted, the sediments are in some places scarcely consolidated.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Noise from current-carrying resistors in the frequency range from 20 kilocycles to 500 kilocycles
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: There are four principal sources of random fluctuation, or noise, arising in amplifier circuits. They are: "shot effect" and "flicker effect" in vacuum tubes, and "thermal noise" and "Bernamont noise" in resistors. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The natural areas of the Montreal metropolitan community with special reference to the central area
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: While the large North American cities are a comparatively recent phenomenon, they have come to play a role in national life, hardly commensurate with their age and amount of territory they occupy. There has been a continual tendency for the city to grow both in population and area at the expense of the rural areas, small towns, and the nearby semi-rural countryside. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Montréal Metropolitan Area (Québec) -- Social conditions
Montréal Metropolitan Area (Québec)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of a scintillation counter
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Detection of ionizing radiations by the fluorescence they cause in certain substances was first performed by Lord Rutherford. It was found that a single a particle on hitting a zinc sulphide screen produced enough light for the flash to be registered visually. This technique could not be applied to other radiations then known (β and γ rays) since these have considerably lower ionizing power and the energy released in the fluorescent screen was below the sensitivity of the eye. The principle however remained and awraited the appearance of a light detecting instrument more sensitive and reliable than the human eye. [...] The object of this experiment was to construct a counter employing a fluorescent screen and a commerical photo-multiplier tube, suitable for work with γ rays. Particular attention was paid to the development of practical ways of reducing the high background rate of the counter, while keeping the intrinsic efficiency at a moderately high level.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The poetic principles of T.S. Eliot
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Thomas Stearns Eliot has unquestionably influenced English poetry. Just how profound this influence is cannot at present be estimated, but up to now he has been without doubt the most influential writer of his time. [...] In the following paper I have therefore tried to examine impartially, in the light that is shed on them by his own poetry, the critical remarks Eliot has made concerning poetry. What emerges from this examination leads to the conclusion that there is a unity, albeit qualified, in Eliot's writings as a whole. [...] I have approached the subject largely from the critical side of Eliot's writings not only because deduction is a more reliable method than induction but also because - etiam disiecti membra poetae notwithstanding - dissection is less damaging to criticism than to poetry.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Eliot, T. S. (Thomas Stearns), 1888-1965

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the binding of gamma-aminobutyric acid and other amino acids by brain
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In recent years increasing attention has been given to the study of inhibitory processes within the nervous system. Many have hoped to define how gammaaminobutyric acid, GABA, a substance that has among the various tissues studied a unique occurrence in the vertebrate nervous system, may be related at a molecular level to the inhibitory process which "is accompanied by a stabilization of membrane polarization in a manner which blocks the depolarizing action of excitatory impulses acting upon the same postsynaptic membrane. This may be called repolarization or hyperpolarization... The essential fact is that the inhibitory process in all nerve cells counteracts the depolarizing action of excitatory processes to maintain the polarization of a cell at an equilibrium level near that of its resting value" [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Anomalous high energy electron scattering
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The theory of quantum electrodynamics has been with us for some time. Techniques of calculation have evolved which produce answers which are in excellent agreement with the experimental results. However, the logical consistency of the procedures is open to question. Debate has continued for some years on the consistency of the formalism, and almost any shade of opinion may be found somewhere in the literature. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Detection with the light and electron microscopes of a carbohydrate - rich cell coat at the surface of cells in the rat
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Over fifty cell types were examined under the light microscope after staining of rat tissues with the periodic acid - Schiff technique for detection of glycoproteins, and colloidal iron at low pH for detection of acidic carbohydrates. With both techniques, nearly all cells investigated were outlined by a thin band of stained material. In epithelia, the stained layer was usually interrupted where two adjacent plasma membranes fused to form tight junctions. This finding indicated that the layer was not part of the plasma membrane itself but rather a "cell coat" located on its outer surface. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Entsagung in Goethes Wanderjahren
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Die Untersuchung beschaftigt sich mit einem der drei grosseren Werkkomplexe (Westostlicher Divan, Faust II, Wilhelm Meister), die das sogenannte Spatwerk J.W. Goethes ausmachen. Diese Werke, also auch die Wanderjahre, untersucht die Germanistik seit langer Zeit. Man muss fragen, was eine neuerliche Eeschaftigung mit den Wanderjahren rechtfertigen kann. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: German

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of factors that control osteogenesis, osteolysis and remodelling reconstruction
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The first effort of primitive man in surgical therapy was an attempt to close a gaping, bleeding wound or fracture. The earliest records of surgical operations in prehistoric periods are found in the bones of the mummified remains. From these it has been found that one of the oldest operations attempted by man, 10,000 years ago, was that of trephine openings in the skull. That some survived this operation is shown by the evidence of repair of bone in the margin of the trephined openings. The earliest records of surgical practice are discovered in the ruins of the temples and monuments. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Acceleration and inhibition of tryptophan metabolism
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Tryptophan is functionally important in biological systems, as the free amine acid, as a component of proteins, and as a precursor of physiologically active substances. If administered in excess amounts, it modifies carbohydrate and fat metabolism and the activities of some enzymes. A dietary deficiency of this essential amino acid results in attenuated growth, and alterations in the metabolism of certain substances. Within the protein molecule, tryptophan is believed to play a role as an intermediate in some enzymic reactions. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of weak locus histoincompatibility in mice
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Until the present century, owing mainly to inadequate observations and perhaps to the legend of a successful transplant of a whole leg from a dead Ethiopian to a devout member of the early church by two "Saints", transplantation was considered to be solely a surgical problem. The careful observations of more recent workers have corrected this misconception. It is now known that a transplant from one non-inbred individual to another of the same species (an allograft), or to one of a different species (a xenograft), enjoys only a brief period of survival. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The use of hypothermia and hyperbaric oxygen in the preservation of kidneys in dogs
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The limited frequency distribution of genetically compatible donor-recipient combination in the natural population added to the uncertainty in assessing the possible adverse effects occasioned by the loss of one kidney to the donor preclude the general use of living donors as the main sources of kidneys in the treatment of irreversible kidney disease. The gratifying results of allografts from cadavers reported in recent years (64a, 143a, 166a, 244a, 305a) make organ preservation technique an imperative armamentarium in transplantation, to complement the efforts to modify the homograft response. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery
